content: What is the recommended way (in the LIPIcs template that will be used for ITP 2023) to link lines in our paper to concrete lines of code in our repository in a way that will eventually survive the subsequent editing process?

Martin Dvořák said:

What is the recommended way (in the LIPIcs template that will be used for ITP 2023) to link lines in our paper to concrete lines of code in our repository in a way that will eventually survive the subsequent editing process?

Playing bad cop: “So your code is not mature enough, huh...?”.
More seriously, if that line is so important, it probably deserves a snippet. Which you should maintain (and yes, bad cop has some point).

In any case, take this suggestion with a grain of salt: I'm not a computer scientist.

Pedro Sánchez Terraf said:

Playing bad cop: “So your code is not mature enough, huh...?”.
More seriously, if that line is so important, it probably deserves a snippet. Which you should maintain (and yes, bad cop has some point).

I don't understand your comment. Nevertheless, I didn't want to start a general discussion about style here.
I would like to hear an authoritative answer from the organizers "write it in this way and the links will survive".
You can create a branch or a fork and link there. And/or you can use a domain you own with a bunch of redirects.
I mean [I should have specified my question better.] how should I typeset the links on the LaTeX side, so that the editors won't eventually kick them out?
@Martin Dvořák I moved your question to a new thread.

I already sent this to Martin Dvořák privately when the thread was in #announce, but now that it's not:

I have a script that exports line number information from my lean project here, with some usage explanation here. If you use something like this then you don't need to carefully manage the links yourself.
It lets you write \leanlink{some_lemma_name} in the paper and it creates a link to the right repo, commit, file, and line number on GitHub.
